subjectInfo.subject: Earthquake ground motions and engineering seismology
Volcano seismology

selfCitationGroup.citation: Hagen, C. J. (2024). Quantitative and nuanced approaches elucidate carbon isotope records. Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems, 25, e2024GC011718. https://doi.org/10.1029/2024GC011718

titleGroup.title: Quantitative and Nuanced Approaches Elucidate Carbon Isotope Records
Hagen

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Earth scientists have leveraged carbon isotope records to interpret Earth history and establish chronostratigraphic frameworks for decades (e.g., Halverson et al., 2005, https://doi.org/10.1130/b25630.1; Kaufman & Knoll, 1995, https://doi.org/10.1016/0301‐9268(94)00070‐8; Knoll et al., 1986, https://doi.org/10.1038/321832a0; Saltzman & Thomas, 2012, https://doi.org/10.1016/b978‐0‐444‐59425‐9.00011‐1; Scholle & Arthur, 1980, https://doi.org/10.1306/2f91892d‐16ce‐11d7‐8645000102c1865d). Increasingly detailed and nuanced approaches have been applied to understanding carbon isotope records in light of local‐ and regional‐scale processes that complicate interpretations. The recent work of Gazdewich et al. (2024, https://doi.org/10.1029/2023gc011376) is a prescient example, in which they conduct a series of analyses to constrain the influence of authigenic carbonate burial on the global carbon isotope mass balance during the Late Devonian. Here, I briefly review some recent developments in quantitative approaches to understanding carbon isotope values measured from carbonate rocks (δ13Ccarb), with a focus on comparisons of measured δ13Ccarb values, models for understanding what controls δ13Ccarb values, and correlation tools for aligning δ13Ccarb stratigraphies. These new approaches are elucidating carbon isotope records across Earth history and may prove to be transformative for our understanding of the global carbon cycle.

abstract.title: Plain Language Summary
abstract.p: The ratio of stable carbon isotopes measured in carbonate rocks (δ13Ccarb) has long been used as a tool for geologists to estimate the relative ages of ancient rocks by matching trends in δ13Ccarb between localities. Recent work has demonstrated that biological and geological processes at local and regional scales can influence δ13Ccarb, making the matching between localities more complicated. Because of this, increasingly detailed and nuanced approaches have been developed to understand trends in δ13Ccarb. Gazdewich et al. (2024, https://doi.org/10.1029/2023gc011376) recently provided a new protocol for constraining the degree to which one of these geological processes–the burial of in situ‐forming carbonate minerals (authigenic carbonate)–impacted δ13Ccarb values during the Late Devonian (382.7–358.9 million years ago). In this commentary, I provide context for this advancement, highlighting other recent developments in quantitative approaches for understanding δ13Ccarb values. These new approaches have the potential to significantly improve our understanding of the global carbon cycle through time, as inferred by changes in δ13Ccarb across Earth history.

listItem.p: Quantitative and nuanced approaches are revealing the impact of local‐ and regional‐scale processes on δ13Ccarb values and correlation
Despite complications, δ13Ccarb correlation still appears to often yield realistic chronostratigraphic frameworks across Earth history
A full accounting of the uncertainties associated δ13Ccarb values is needed for future interpretations, and to improve our understanding of the global carbon cycle across Earth history

section.title: Introduction
section.p: Carbon isotope records from carbonate rocks (δ13Ccarb) underpin much of our understanding of ancient carbon cycle dynamics and events throughout Earth history, serving as both a proxy for paleoclimate and a basis for building chronostratigraphic frameworks. Traditionally, δ13Ccarb records have often been interpreted to represent changes in the amount of organic carbon buried in the oceans (e.g., Kump & Arthur, 1999; although note that Kump and Arthur (1999) highlighted a number of additional mechanisms for driving δ13Ccarb excursions). Recent work by Gazdewich et al. (2024) investigated key carbon isotope records from the Late Devonian, looking for evidence that authigenic carbonate burial impacted the global carbon isotope mass balance. Through a series of quantitative analyses and sedimentary lithofacies comparisons, they conclude that there is no evidence that authigenic carbonate played a large role in the Late Devonian global carbon cycle. This is important because authigenic carbonate has been suggested as a potential explanation for large δ13Ccarb variations throughout Earth history (Schrag et al., 2013) and has been found to be non‐negligible in the modern global carbon cycle (Sun & Turchyn, 2014). Overall Gazdewich et al. (2024) concludes that authigenic carbonate contributions can be identified in ancient carbonate rocks. They also offer an exportable workflow that can be applied to other intervals of Earth history when authigenic carbonate has been invoked to explain carbon isotope dynamics to determine how large of a role this process may have played. This work highlights the growing number of studies using increasingly detailed techniques for investigating carbon isotope fluctuations, leading to more nuanced interpretations.

section.title: Increasingly Detailed Techniques for Carbon Isotope Stratigraphy
section.p: Recent and ongoing work is exploring and developing new quantitative techniques for addressing questions related to carbon isotope stratigraphy. Although note that there are certainly important, quantitative studies related to carbon isotope stratigraphy in the past that inform and facilitate current and future work in this area (e.g., Kump, 1991; Panchuk et al., 2005, 2006, 2008; Payne & Kump, 2007). This current work is focused on three broad areas: comparisons of measured δ13Ccarb values; models for understanding what controls δ13Ccarb values; and correlation tools for aligning δ13Ccarb stratigraphies. Carbon isotope values have been compared quantitatively and systematically in recent work, including Gazdewich et al. (2024), often comparing values measured from different sedimentary lithofacies (e.g., Geyman & Maloof, 2021; Ingalls et al., 2020; Prave et al., 2021). This work is providing essential background for interpreting δ13Ccarb records, as it demonstrates that it is plausible that a change in lithofacies could result in a change in recorded δ13Ccarb values. There has also been a lot of effort to improve carbon isotope modeling, both on local and global scales (e.g., Geyman & Maloof, 2019; Lenton et al., 2018; Trower et al., 2024). By better understanding how global biogeochemical cycles interact and manifest carbon isotopic changes (Lenton et al., 2018), and how carbon isotope values change throughout the day due to photosynthesis and diurnal biogeochemical cycling (Geyman & Maloof, 2019; Trower et al., 2024), we are getting closer to being able to accurately model specific carbon isotope records. Lastly, δ13Ccarb correlation has seen recent improvement with the introduction of a new mathematical algorithm aimed at aligning δ13Ccarb records (Ajayi et al., 2020; Hagen & Creveling, 2024; Hagen et al., 2024; Hay et al., 2019; Reynolds, 2023). This algorithmic approach, referred to as Align (Hagen et al., 2024), allows users to explore a variety of possible δ13Ccarb alignments (producing an alignment library) and can project the stratigraphic position of each individual δ13Ccarb value (Hay et al., 2019). Importantly, this algorithm for stratigraphic correlation can be combined with Bayesian age modeling (e.g., Haslett & Parnell, 2008; Schoene et al., 2019; Trayler et al., 2019), using the projected position of available geochronologic age constraints as a selection criterion to select a specific alignment from libraries of possibilities, thereby combining all of the available geochronologic constraints from individual δ13Ccarb records into a single Bayesian age model for the resulting composite δ13Ccarb record (Hagen & Creveling, 2024). Note that while there are significant benefits to using quantitative stratigraphic correlation methods, they cannot mitigate inherent uncertainty. For example, it is not possible to prove that a limited portion of δ13Ccarb stratigraphy (such as a single excursion) in a record with little‐to‐no chronologic constraints is temporally equivalent to a portion of δ13Ccarb stratigraphy in another record (when using δ13Ccarb alignment as the sole evidence), regardless of whether quantitative or qualitative alignment techniques are employed.

section.title: Nuanced Interpretations of Carbon Isotope Excursions
section.p: As increasingly detailed techniques are applied to the δ13Ccarb record, our interpretations of past δ13Ccarb events can become more nuanced. We need not always prescribe extraordinary circumstances that allow for a single mechanism to drive a specific carbon isotope excursion (CIE). Instead, we can further explore how multiple mechanisms, under more typical conditions that would not allow for any of these mechanisms to account for the full CIE on their own, could conspire together to drive the CIE. Take, for example, the Neoproterozoic Shuram negative CIE (e.g., Burns & Matter, 1993; Calver, 2000; Fike et al., 2006), one of the largest documented excursions in Earth history, the cause of which has been the subject of debate for decades (e.g., Burns & Matter, 1993; Busch et al., 2022; Rothman et al., 2003; Schrag et al., 2013). The Shuram CIE is characterized by a negative δ13Ccarb shift of ∼12‰ and a global distribution (e.g., Grotzinger et al., 2011; Figure 1), with a purportedly synchronous occurrence between 574.0 ± 4.7 Ma and 567.3 ± 3.0 Ma (Rooney et al., 2020). Furthermore, the Shuram CIE negative shift and subsequent recovery has been constrained to have occurred in 2.06 ± 1.87 Myr and 3.56 ± 1.92 Myr, respectively (Hagen & Creveling, 2024). Many hypothesized mechanisms have been put forth to explain the CIE, typically either invoking significant alterations to carbon cycle dynamics (e.g., Johnston et al., 2012; Rothman et al., 2003; Shields, 2017) or transient reservoir partitioning (temporary changes to the distribution of carbon in major reservoirs; e.g., Bjerrum & Canfield, 2011; Schrag et al., 2013; Paulsen et al., 2017). Furthermore, decoupled covariation between marine organic and carbonate carbon is often inferred to reflect an enhanced dissolved organic carbon reservoir (Halverson et al., 2005; Lee et al., 2015). Despite this wealth of previous work, no mechanism has been able to accommodate all geologic and chronologic aspects of the CIE. Some previous studies have proposed that the CIE is the result of diagenesis and does not represent a primary record of the dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) reservoir (e.g., Derry, 2010; Knauth & Kennedy, 2009), however subsequent work has found little evidence to support these hypotheses (Busch et al., 2022). Techniques designed to assess the impact of specific processes on a given δ13Ccarb record could prove very useful for understanding δ13Ccarb excursions, such as the recent work by Gazdewich et al. (2024). Perhaps the true solution to the Shuram CIE lies in a nuanced combination of these myriad mechanisms, and new quantitative approaches offer an opportunity to investigate this mystery. For example, Busch et al. (2022) proposed that a global transgression isolated individual carbonate ramps from the global ocean, allowing for local‐scale processes, such as a diurnal carbon engine (e.g., Geyman & Maloof, 2019; Trower et al., 2024) or primary productivity‐driven CO2 invasion (Ahm et al., 2021), to drive a globally synchronous CIE.

caption.p: Neoproterozoic δ13Ccarb evolution. An abbreviated composite Neoproterozoic δ13Ccarb record (purple data; built using published data from Amthor et al. (2003), Fike et al. (2006), Maloof et al. (2010), and Turner and Bekker (2016)). Gray bars indicate glacial intervals (e.g., Rooney et al., 2015), with labels on the right. Major, named carbon isotope excursions (CIEs) are indicated with labels and arrows. Translucent teal bars and dashed lines indicate the evolution in carbon isotope plateaus (CIPs), with a background δ13Ccarb value of ≥5‰ during the Tonian Period transitioning to a typical background δ13Ccarb value (0‰) by the early Cambrian.

section.p: In addition to the Shuram CIE, there are multiple other large negative CIEs documented from the Neoproterozoic Era (Figure 1). While the same combination of mechanisms may have repeatedly perturbed the global carbon cycle during this interval, it is also possible that different mechanism combinations (or different relative contributions of each mechanism in a given combination) led to each of these CIEs. In addition to multiple negative CIEs, the Neoproterozoic δ13Ccarb record is also characterized by protracted intervals of elevated δ13Ccarb (e.g., Ahm et al., 2021), or carbon isotope plateaus (CIPs). During the Tonian, these CIPs have δ13Ccarb values >5‰ (Figure 1). These CIP values transition from >5‰ at the beginning of the Cryogenian to ∼2‰ in the early Ediacaran (Figure 1). Following the Shuram CIE, CIP values transition to ∼0‰ by the Precambrian–Cambrian boundary (Figure 1). This trend in CIPs has not been directly addressed by previous work but one possible explanation is that heightened primary productivity (Gao et al., 2020), and therefore heightened organic carbon burial, elevated background δ13CDIC for most of the Neoproterozoic (Busch et al., 2022). This possible productivity–organic carbon export trend would likely be closely linked to sympathetic trends in oxygen inventories and redox state, which is an area of active research (e.g., Cui et al., 2017; Gutarra et al., 2024; Johnston et al., 2010; Kendall et al., 2015; Lyons et al., 2009; Sahoo et al., 2016). Perhaps the Neoproterozoic CIPs could even have been driven by authigenic carbonate burial, which could be tested with the new approach detailed by Gazdewich et al. (2024). However, these single mechanism explanations lack much nuance and require further investigation of these Neoproterozoic CIPs.

section.title: Carbon Isotopic Fidelity
section.p: There are many reasons to question absolute δ13Ccarb values, as recent work has demonstrated that many processes compete to shape the resulting measured value. For example, local‐scale primary biological processes can perturb δ13Ccarb values from background values, whether this is the result of the diurnal carbon engine (perturbing values heavy (higher) relative to background δ13CDIC; Geyman & Maloof, 2019; Trower et al., 2024) or vital effects (perturbing values light (lower) relative to background δ13CDIC; Erez, 1978; Gischler et al., 2009). Sedimentary lithofacies may alias local δ13Ccarb records, complicating regional and global isotopic correlations (e.g., Geyman & Maloof, 2021; Ingalls et al., 2020). Perhaps focusing δ13Ccarb analyses on a single lithofacies, such as micrite, could yield records more reflective of regional–global isotopic trends (see Geyman & Maloof, 2021). Regional‐scale processes can further complicate the interpretation and correlation of δ13Ccarb records, such as through the establishment of shelf‐scale gradients in δ13Ccarb values (e.g., Jiang et al., 2007; Panchuk et al., 2005, 2006) and variable depositional histories that sub‐sample background δ13CDIC (e.g., Myrow & Grotzinger, 2000). Previous work has proposed that authigenic carbonate could have driven δ13Ccarb excursions, such as the Shuram CIE (Schrag et al., 2013), and recent work by Gazdewich et al. (2024) demonstrates how to assess its impact on δ13Ccarb records. In addition to processes that shape primary δ13Ccarb values prior to and during carbonate mineral precipitation, extensive work in modern carbonate systems has demonstrated the potential for diagenesis to secondarily alter δ13Ccarb values (e.g., Ahm et al., 2018; Higgins et al., 2018; Swart & Oehlert, 2018). Given the myriad of reasons to suspect that δ13Ccarb records may not predominantly reflect changes in global δ13CDIC, it is not surprising that some members of the Earth history and stratigraphy communities question the utility of global δ13Ccarb correlation (e.g., Derry, 2010; Knauth & Kennedy, 2009; Prave et al., 2021; Swart, 2008). And yet, seemingly against all odds, δ13Ccarb correlation appears to work quite well across Earth history (e.g., Hagen & Creveling, 2024; Saltzman & Thomas, 2012; Zachos et al., 2001), leading many members of the Earth history and stratigraphy communities to continue aligning δ13Ccarb records despite these complications.

section.title: Future Work and Societal Relevance
section.p: Recent quantitative developments in our understanding and treatment of δ13Ccarb records are leading to an improved understanding of global carbon cycle dynamics and chronostratigraphic frameworks. Future work that could lead to transformative applications of δ13Ccarb stratigraphy includes new process‐based numerical models to fully simulate δ13Ccarb values in a variety of depositional environments, the establishment of uncertainty estimates for δ13Ccarb values that reflect local‐scale and diagenetic processes, and updated δ13Ccarb correlation schemes that can account for uncertainty in δ13Ccarb values. The recent work by Gazdewich et al. (2024) demonstrates a new analytical protocol that can be employed to probe the influence of authigenic carbonate burial on the global carbon isotope mass balance at different times throughout Earth history. Gazdewich et al. (2024) finds that there is no evidence that authigenic carbonate played a large role in the Late Devonian global carbon cycle. Because the Late Devonian is also marked by one of the five major mass extinctions, dynamic sea‐level change, and a cooling of global climate (e.g., Sandberg et al., 2002), it is particularly important to understand the global carbon cycle during this time. As we increase our understanding of δ13Ccarb records, we will be able to better constrain the global carbon cycle across Earth history, ultimately improving our ability to understand modern biogeochemical dynamics and future climate change.

section.title: Acknowledgments
section.p: I thank J. Creveling and E. Trower for their feedback on this commentary. I also thank A.‐S. Ahm, H. Cui, A. Mix, A. Maloof, E. Brook, C. Reimers, M. Webster, E. Geyman, A. Mehra, B. Howes, C. Hay, P. Huybers, J. Higgins, M. Nadeau, P. Reynolds, K. Snell, J. Creveling, and E. Trower for countless past conversations that have challenged and helped shape my perspective on carbon isotope stratigraphy. I also thank L. Kump and one anonymous reviewer for their constructive feedback that greatly improved this contribution, as well as editor B. Williams for the invitation to write this commentary and their editorial handling.

section.title: Conflict of Interest
section.p: The author declares no conflicts of interest relevant to this study.

section.title: Data Availability Statement
section.p: All data used in this commentary are available in the material cited in the reference list (Amthor et al., 2003; Fike et al., 2006; Maloof et al., 2010; Turner & Bekker, 2016).
